Award.AwardTitle: Antiferromagnetic Spin Torque Devices for Terahertz Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: Development of very high speed nanoscale magnetic devices in which current induced spin torque is used to initiate and control ultrafast spin dynamics in antiferromagnets.

Intellectual Merit: In antiferromagnets the sublattice moments are coupled via strong exchange fields that cause the frequencies of the spin-wave modes to be in the 1.0-3.0 terahertz range, and, consequently, spin dynamics in antiferromagnets evolve on sub-picosecond time-scales. Antiferromagnets offer the promise of increasing the operating speeds of magnetic devices by 2-3 orders of magnitude. The proposed research aims to develop a new family of nanoscale magnetic devices, such as oscillators and switches, in which current induced spin torque is used to initiate and control spin dynamics in antiferromagnetic spin valves. The research proposed here is transformative and would not just open new doors for ultrahigh speed nanoscale devices but also contribute significantly towards the understanding of the fundamental material science and spin physics of antiferromagnets.

Broader Impacts: The proposed project will support the research of two graduate students and two undergraduate students at Cornell University and provide a rich set of areas for graduate student research. The PI will introduce a new 2-3 credit hour freshman/sophomore level course related to nanosciences with the goal of attracting freshmen/sophomores to related disciplines. The PI and the graduate students will participate in Cornell's K-12 outreach efforts by developing an introductory workshop on nanostructures, with a laboratory component, for high school students. Under a USAID international development program the PI will help organize teacher training workshops in Pakistan.

.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to control spin states in magnetic devices has led to tremendous advancements in science and technology. For example, commonly used magnetic non-volatile memory devices include computer hard drives and tape-drives. Conventional magnetic devices are made from ferromagnetic materials. In ferromagnetic materials spin dynamics are slow and evolve on nanosecond time scales. In contrast, DRAM memories in computers can switch on tens of picosecond time scales, but they are volatile and need to be periodically refreshed. Flash memories (i.e. USB sticks) are non-volatile but switch on microsecond time scales. There is a great need for memory devices that are both non-volatile and switch on picosecond time scales.

The goal of this research project was to explore and harness the fast spin dynamics in certain magnetic materials, called the antiferromagnets, to realize non-volatile memory devices that switch on picosecond time scales and also realize nanoscale terahertz-frequency electrical oscillators. Our efforts resulted in three major achievements:

1) We developed a family of techniques to excite and measure spin dynamics in antiferromagnetic materials with sub-picosecond time scale resolution. These capabilities are critical for conducting research on antiferromagnets.

2) We explored several techniques to excite spin dynamics and spin swithing in antiferromagnets using electrical currents.

3) We also explored several techniques to electrically observe fast spin dynamics using the inverse of spin Hall effect.

Our research showed many signatures previously predicted by theories on antiferromagnetic spin dynamics and switching. Much more work is needed to clean up or experimental data from parasitic effects and to go from our preliminary results to actual functioning devices that meet the commercial needs.
